hints_html: From part (b) we have the direction which makes the directional derivative smallest. What is the actual value of the directional derivative in this direction?
hints_latex:
From
{part
(b)} we have the direction which makes the directional derivative
smallest. What is the actual value of the directional derivative in this
direction?
hints_raw: From [[Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH200/April_2012/Question_04_(b)|part (b)]] we have the direction which makes the directional derivative smallest.  What is the actual value of the directional derivative in this direction?
question: 4 (c)
sols_html:
When T is decreasing most rapidly from its value at P, the actual rate of change (a scalar) is based on the direction chosen in part (b):

\[\begin{aligned} D_{\widehat{\mathbf{u}}} T(1,2,-1) &= \nabla T(1,2,-1)\cdot \frac{-\nabla T(1,2,-1)}{\left\vert -\nabla T(1,2,-1)\right\vert} \\ &= \frac{-\left\vert{\nabla T(1,2,-1)}\right\vert^2 }{\left\vert \nabla T(1,2,-1)\right\vert} \\ &= -\left\vert{\nabla T(1,2,-1)}\right\vert \\ &= -10 e^{-9}\sqrt{17}.\end{aligned}\]

This has units of \(\displaystyle {}\text{C}/\text{m}\).

In plain English, the words can absorb the minus sign: ”The maximum rate of decrease of temperature at point P is

\[\begin{aligned} 10 e^{-9}\sqrt{17} \text{C}/\text{m}\end{aligned}\]

obtained in the direction \(\left\langle 2,2,-3\right\rangle/\sqrt{17}\).”
sols_latex:
When \emph{T} is decreasing most rapidly from its value at \emph{P}, the
actual rate of change (a scalar) is based on the direction chosen in
{part
(b)}:

\begin{align*}
D_{\widehat{\mathbf{u}}} T(1,2,-1)
&= \nabla T(1,2,-1)\cdot \frac{-\nabla T(1,2,-1)}{\left\vert -\nabla T(1,2,-1)\right\vert} \\
&= \frac{-\left\vert{\nabla T(1,2,-1)}\right\vert^2 }{\left\vert \nabla T(1,2,-1)\right\vert} \\
&= -\left\vert{\nabla T(1,2,-1)}\right\vert \\
&= -10 e^{-9}\sqrt{17}.
\end{align*}

This has units of $\displaystyle {}\text{C}/\text{m}$.

In plain English, the words can absorb the minus sign: ''The maximum
rate of decrease of temperature at point \emph{P} is

\begin{align*}
10 e^{-9}\sqrt{17} \text{C}/\text{m}
\end{align*}

obtained in the direction
$\left\langle 2,2,-3\right\rangle/\sqrt{17}$.''
sols_raw:
When ''T'' is decreasing most rapidly from its value at ''P'', the actual rate of change (a scalar) is based on the direction chosen in [[Science:Math Exam Resources/Courses/MATH200/April 2012/Question 04 (b)|part (b)]]:
:<math>
\begin{align}
D_{\widehat{\mathbf{u}}} T(1,2,-1)
&= \nabla T(1,2,-1)\cdot \frac{-\nabla T(1,2,-1)}{\left\vert -\nabla T(1,2,-1)\right\vert} \\
&= \frac{-\left\vert{\nabla T(1,2,-1)}\right\vert^2 }{\left\vert \nabla T(1,2,-1)\right\vert} \\
&= -\left\vert{\nabla T(1,2,-1)}\right\vert \\
&= -10 e^{-9}\sqrt{17}.
\end{align}
</math>

This has units of <math>\displaystyle{}\text{C}/\text{m}</math>.

In plain English, the words can absorb the minus sign: ''The maximum rate of decrease of temperature at point ''P'' is

:<math> 10 e^{-9}\sqrt{17} \text{C}/\text{m}</math>

obtained in the direction <math>\left\langle 2,2,-3\right\rangle/\sqrt{17}</math>.''
statement_html:
The temperature at a point (x,y,z) is given by

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle{}T(x,y,z)=5\exp(-2x^2-y^2-3z^2)\end{aligned}\]

where T is measured in centigrade and x,y,z in metres.

Find the maximum rate of decrease at P.
statement_raw:
The temperature at a point (x,y,z) is given by

:<math>
\displaystyle{}T(x,y,z)=5\exp(-2x^2-y^2-3z^2)
</math>

where T is measured in centigrade and x,y,z in metres.

Find the maximum rate of decrease at P.
